learning_outcomes.description: Explain the dynamics of motivation and how this impacts on visitors' experiences in a range of tourism, hospitality and events settings
Apply the key principles of visitor learning, interpretation and orientation to the design of visitor experiences
Identify and manage environmental, social and cross-cultural impacts in visitor settings
Develop strategies and recommendations for the management of visitor experiences in tourism, hospitality and event operations and destinations
Critically evaluate a visitor experience using a range of evaluation tools and approaches.

assessments.task_description:
Select a suitable visitor attraction and conduct a critique of the site in terms of visitor learning experiences and visitor management. 

You CANNOT choose the Queensland Museum as we will be visiting this site as a field trip.

You will be doing this from the perspective of ONE particular target market of your choice (eg. primary school children on excursions; families with teenage children; Australian retirees with an interest in history etc). 

Word Limit: 1000 words

You are required to:

  • Select a visitor site that offers some level or type of visitor learning. You will need to visit the site but can also use virtual tours and other online resources to inform your critique.
  • Using the guidelines from the Queensland Museum field trip, write a critique of the various visitor facilities and services offered at your chosen site.
  • Include photographs to illustrate your points, including a selfie of you at your site.


PART 1: BACKGROUND

  • Describe the site – what is it (museum, national park etc), where is it, how long has it been there etc.
  • Provide a map or diagram of the site
  • Identify ONE target market that you will be using as the basis of your report and briefly discuss their likely motives and interests. 


PART 2: CRITIQUE

Drawing from relevant lecture content and using the checklist provided, note how well the site is likely to meet the needs and interests of the ONE target market you have identified. In particular, you should discuss:

  • Entrance/welcoming area
  • Visitor facilities
  • Visitor comfort
  • Orientation (both internal and external directional signs)
  • Visitor engagement
  • Interpretive signs
  • Exhibit design issues
  • Maintenance
  • Highlight the areas and aspects that are done well and those that could be improved. Justify this with your on-site observations and photographs.

A template will be provided on Blackboard for submitting this assessment.

Assessment 1 (Critique of Visitor Site) and Assessment 2 (Management Consultant Briefing) are related. The critique you develop in Assessment 1 and the feedback given will be used as the basis of Assessment 2.

AI Statement

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The assignment must be submitted electronically via Turnitin located in the Blackboard Assessment link.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
Week 7 - Week 8

Week 7 - Week 8

This is an in-class assessment.
assessments.task_description:
Assessment 1 (Critique of Visitor Site) and Assessment 2 (Management Consultant Briefing) are related. The critique you have developed in Assessment 1 and the feedback given will be used as the basis of Assessment 2.

As a consultant, provide the manager of a tourism operation with recommendations for enhancing the visitor experience for a target market. The recommendations are based on your first assessment (Site Critique Task). 

You will be doing this from the perspective of ONE target market of your choice (e.g. primary school children on field trips; families with teenage children; international tourists on a tour etc). 

Consultant Briefing

The recommendations are to be presented as a consultant in a 10 min professional (oral) conversation with the tourism manager. Your course coordinator or tutor will role play the tourism manager. 

Format

The meeting will consist of two parts:

Part 1 - Presenting 2–3 priority recommendations

Your recommendations are directly related to the Site Critique task you submitted earlier and should:

• Provide suggestions for improvements to the identified weaknesses. You can also provide suggestions for how the site can further improve their strengths.

• Be clearly linked to the needs and preferences of the ONE target market you have selected.

• Be innovative, strategic, feasible, realistic and measurable.

Clearly state what is recommended and how to achieve this. For example, it is insufficient to say there are no multi-lingual signs so the recommendation is to install multi-lingual signs. Rather, you should be stating WHY multilingual signs would be beneficial, WHERE they should be placed and WHAT specific languages should be considered. 

Part 2 - Conversation with your manager

You will be asked questions about your recommendations. Specifically, you will be asked about:

• how you applied what you learned about the key principles of the visitor experience in the course so far to the design of your recommendations.

• your recommendations with regards to your research in the Site Critique and learning in the first part of the course.

Purpose

The task is an opportunity to: 

• Propose evidence based, feasible recommendations that improve visitor experience, accessibility, sustainability, cultural safety, and commercial outcomes.

• Showcase your knowledge and learning situated in a scenario aligned to a workplace/professional scenario.

• Develop your skills to communicate professionally with a manager in the tourism sector.

No printed materials or notes are to be used for this briefing.

Please Note: The presentation will be recorded for marking purposes per UQ Policy.

AI-Statement

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This is an oral assessment task and must be delivered in person.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
FACILITY DESIGN PROPOSAL 

Word Count: Approx. 3,500

This is an individual assignment that requires you to design an ORIGINAL tourism/event or hospitality facility. Choose from one of the following categories:

  • a theme park, zoo, or cultural attraction
  • a museum, art gallery or historic building
  • a resort, health spa, hotel/casino complex (NOT A GYM)
  • an entertainment complex


PART 1: Introduction

Overview of proposal

  • an overview of the design concept.
  • brief background information about the location of your facility and its surroundings.
  • explanation of facility name.

Target Market, motives and interests

In this section you should identify ONE market segment that you feel will be particularly attracted to the facility that you are proposing:

  • Who are they, what are they interested in?
  • Why is your facility likely to attract this market? Why do you think your proposal will be successful? Here you should briefly justify with literature dealing with the type of facility that you are proposing. The literature can include trade journals, media reports and non-academic sources if relevant.


PART 2: Design elements

Theme

  • What are the underlying concept or ideas linking the elements together?
  • What is the key thing you want visitors to think, feel or do as a result of visiting your facility?

Layout and Orientation

  • Design a map or site plan of the facility. Describe and justify your layout.
  • Describe the different ‘areas’ and explain how the site has been designed to facilitate visitor use, flows and movement.
  • If relevant, explain how you would manage queues, crowding and capacity issues.

Design elements

  • Describe how you intend to use ambient features (lighting, music, colour, décor) to support your theme and enhance your visitors’ experiences.
  • Describe the activities and experiences that will be offered. Explain how these support your theme.
  • Provide photos and diagrams to illustrate your design ideas.

Managing Impacts

Describe how you will manage the on-site visitor experience:

  • Identify one environmental impact and one socio-cultural impact that your facility could create. These can be both positive, both negative, or one of each. Any combination is permissible, but only identify two in total.
  • Explain what visitor management strategies you would use to minimise/maximise the two identified impacts.

REFERENCE LIST 

APPENDICES (OPTIONAL)

Insert illustrations into the text of your assignment. The appendices is for diagrams, graphs or tables you would like to refer to as supporting information. Appendices and references are not included in the word limit.

AI Statement

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction: What is Visitor Management?

Course Introduction, Overview and Orientation Activities:

This first week we will get to know each other and ensure we have a shared understanding of the key terms used in this course. We will also explore the course profile so you know where to look for key information throughout the semester.


Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_description: Introduction: What is Visitor Management? Course Introduction, Overview and Orientation Activities: This first week we will get to know each other and ensure we have a shared understanding of the key terms used in this course. We will also explore the course profile so you know where to look for key information throughout the semester.

learning_activities.topic:
Understanding your visitors: Motives and target markets

It is important to understand our visitors, in particular their motives for the visitor experiences they seek. We will explore different target markets and their motivations. This sets the scene for a more indepth discussion about the importance of visitor interpretation next week.

Activities will relate to understanding different target markets, (including undertaking a personality quiz) and tourist motivations.



Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_title: Understanding your visitors: Motives and target markets
learning_activities.topic_description: Understanding your visitors: Motives and target markets It is important to understand our visitors, in particular their motives for the visitor experiences they seek. We will explore different target markets and their motivations. This sets the scene for a more indepth discussion about the importance of visitor interpretation next week. Activities will relate to understanding different target markets, (including undertaking a personality quiz) and tourist motivations.

learning_activities.topic:
Interpretation: Principles and practices of interpretation

This week we will delve into the importance of understanding visitor interpretation. What is it and how can tourism providers do it well? We will build interpretation skills by incorporating a storytelling exercise.


Learning outcomes: L02, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Interpretation: Principles and practices of interpretation This week we will delve into the importance of understanding visitor interpretation. What is it and how can tourism providers do it well? We will build interpretation skills by incorporating a storytelling exercise.

learning_activities.topic:
Designing Interpretive Signs: Principles & Pitfalls

Continuing with our understanding of visitor interpretation, this week we will critically evaluate the suitability and effectiveness of signs in different TH&E contexts. To do this, we will get out of the classroom and explore UQ campus museums and various visitor spaces around the campus.


Learning outcomes: L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Designing Interpretive Signs: Principles & Pitfalls Continuing with our understanding of visitor interpretation, this week we will critically evaluate the suitability and effectiveness of signs in different TH&E contexts. To do this, we will get out of the classroom and explore UQ campus museums and various visitor spaces around the campus.

learning_activities.topic:
Visitor Studies: Field trip to Queensland Museum

Evaluating visitor experiences through field work. This will be a practical and applied class excursion to the QLD Museum at Southbank. All the details will be provided in class.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Principles of Design: Colour, soundscapes, textual factors & spatial design

This week we investigate the fascinating principles of site and experience design and how use of colours and sounds can make or break a visitor experience. Activities will be related to understanding the impact of colour, soundscapes, textual factors and spatial design on the visitor experience.

Learning outcomes: L02, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Principles of Design: Colour, soundscapes, textual factors & spatial design
learning_activities.topic_description: Principles of Design: Colour, soundscapes, textual factors & spatial design This week we investigate the fascinating principles of site and experience design and how use of colours and sounds can make or break a visitor experience. Activities will be related to understanding the impact of colour, soundscapes, textual factors and spatial design on the visitor experience.

learning_activities.topic:
Designing Visitor Experiences

It sounds easy but designing quality visitor experiences takes skill and creativity. This week's activities are related to creating multi-sensory experiences and themed tourist spaces and attractions. This will help generate some great ideas for the final assignment.

Learning outcomes: L02, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Designing Visitor Experiences It sounds easy but designing quality visitor experiences takes skill and creativity. This week's activities are related to creating multi-sensory experiences and themed tourist spaces and attractions. This will help generate some great ideas for the final assignment.

learning_activities.topic:
Managing crowds, queues & risks

Nobody really likes waiting in line for anything! As providers of effective visitor experiences we need to develop strategies for managing large numbers of visitors at a tourist attraction. Activities will relate to this important aspect.

Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Managing crowds, queues & risks Nobody really likes waiting in line for anything! As providers of effective visitor experiences we need to develop strategies for managing large numbers of visitors at a tourist attraction. Activities will relate to this important aspect.

learning_activities.topic:
Managing Visitor Impacts

This week we examine major visitor impacts that can ruin great experiences. We will discuss effective approaches to managing visitors’ impacts on communities and the built and natural environment. This content will assist with the final assignment.

Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Managing Visitor Impacts This week we examine major visitor impacts that can ruin great experiences. We will discuss effective approaches to managing visitors’ impacts on communities and the built and natural environment. This content will assist with the final assignment.

learning_activities.topic:
Future Trends in Visitor Management: Future trends and challenges; the role of technology

This is the final week and we will wrap up with a discussion on visitor management challenges of the future. We might even finish with a super interactive and engaging Digital Escape Box Activity!

Learning outcomes: L02, L04, L05
